{{redirect|Global Fund|other uses|The Global Fund for Children|and|Global Fund for Women}} {{Infobox non-profit | name = The Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria | image = The Global Fund logo.png | founded_date = {{Start date|2002|1|28}} (first Board of Directors meeting) | founder = | location = [[Geneva, Switzerland]] | coordinates = <!-- {{Coord|LAT|LON|display=inline,title}} --> | origins = | key_people = [[Peter Sands (banker)|Peter Sands]], (Executive Director, March 2018 -) | area_served = | product = | focus = Accelerating the end of AIDS, tuberculosis and malaria as epidemics | method = | homepage = {{URL|http://www.theglobalfund.org}} }}
'''The Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria''' (or simply '''the Global Fund''') is an international [[financing]] organization that aims to “attract, leverage and invest additional resources to end the epidemics of [[HIV/AIDS]], [[tuberculosis]] and [[malaria]] to support attainment of the [[Sustainable Development Goals]] established by the [[United Nations]].”<ref>{{cite web |title=Bylaws of the Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis & Malaria |url=https://www.theglobalfund.org/media/6007/core_globalfund_bylaws_en.pdf |website=The Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria |publisher=The Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria |accessdate=28 January 2016}}</ref> A [[public–private partnership|public-private partnership]], the organization maintains its [[Secretariat (administrative office)|secretariat]] in [[Geneva]], [[Switzerland]].<ref>{{cite web|title=GFATM - The Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria|url=https://www.dfae.admin.ch/deza/en/home/partnerships-mandates/partnerships-multilateral-organisations/weitere-organisationen-netzwerke/gfatm.html|website=Swiss Agency for Development and Cooperation SDC|publisher=Swiss Agency for Development and Cooperation SDC|accessdate=23 May 2018}}</ref> The organization began operations in January 2002.<ref>{{cite web|title=GFATM - The Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria|url=https://www.dfae.admin.ch/deza/en/home/partnerships-mandates/partnerships-multilateral-organisations/weitere-organisationen-netzwerke/gfatm.html|website=Swiss Agency for Development and Cooperation SDC|publisher=Swiss Agency for Development and Cooperation SDC|accessdate=23 May 2018}}</ref> [[Microsoft]] founder [[Bill Gates]] was one of the first private foundations among many bilateral donors to provide [[seed money]] for the partnership.<ref name="google1">{{cite web |url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5h6Ih8CYz1SqAKYjI-SiowJgu8BSA?docId=CNG.07d4a47a8ce76f0e07e322726bdf65a2.6f1 |archiveurl=https://archive.fo/20130124180843/http://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5h6Ih8CYz1SqAKYjI-SiowJgu8BSA?docId=CNG.07d4a47a8ce76f0e07e322726bdf65a2.6f1 |archivedate=January 24, 2013 |title=AFP: Global Fund faces billion-dollar gap |publisher=Google.com |date=2011-05-19 |accessdate=2012-01-26 |first=Marlowe |last=Hood |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
The Global Fund is the world's largest financier of AIDS, TB, and malaria prevention, treatment, and care programs.<ref>{{cite news|title=Why The U.S. Is Pledging $4.3 Billion To The Global Fund|url=https://www.npr.org/sections/goatsandsoda/2016/09/15/493760787/why-the-u-s-is-pledging-4-3-billion-to-the-global-fund|accessdate=23 May 2018|publisher=National Public Radio, Inc.|date=15 September 2016}}</ref> As of July 2018, the organization had disbursed more than USD 38 billion to support these programs.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theglobalfund.org/en/financials|title=Financials|last=|first=|date=|website=The Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria|publisher=The Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=13 September 2018}}</ref> According to the organization, in 2017 it financed the distribution of 197 million [[Mosquito net|insecticide-treated nets]] to combat [[malaria]], provided anti-tuberculosis treatment for 5 million people, supported 17.5 million people on antiretroviral therapy for AIDS, and since its founding saved 27 million lives worldwide.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theglobalfund.org/media/7741/corporate_2018resultsreport_report_en.pdf|title=Results Report 2018|last=|first=|date=September 2018|website=The Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria|publisher=The Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=13 September 2018}}</ref>
The Global Fund is a financing mechanism rather than an implementing agency. Programs are implemented by in-country partners such as ministries of health, while the Global Fund secretariat, whose staff only have an office in Geneva, monitor the programs. Implementation is overseen by Country Coordinating Mechanisms, country-level committees consisting of in-country stakeholders that need to include, according to Global Fund requirements, a broad spectrum of representatives from government, NGOs, faith-based organizations, the private sector, and people living with the diseases. This system has kept the Global Fund secretariat smaller than other international bureaucracies. The model has also raised concerns about conflict of interest, as some of the stakeholders represented on the Country Coordinating Mechanisms may also receive money from the Global Fund, either as grant recipients, sub-recipients, private persons (e.g. for travel or participation at seminars) or contractors.
==Creation== At the end of the 20th century, international political will to improve coordinated efforts to fight the world's deadliest infectious diseases began to materialize. Through various multilateral fora, consensus around creating a new international financial vehicle to combat these diseases emerged. In this context the [[World Health Organization]] called for a "Massive Attack on Diseases of Poverty" in December 1999. The original concept suggested tackling “malaria, tuberculosis, unsafe pregnancy, AIDS, diarrheal diseases, acute respiratory infections and measles.”<ref>Executive Director, Director-General’s Office, “Massive Attack on Poverty – A Concept Paper” (paper to WHO Cabinet, Geneva, Dec. 20, 1999.</ref> This list would steadily narrow to only include the three diseases the Global Fund fights today: HIV/AIDS, TB, and malaria.<ref>”Executive Director, Director-General’s Office, “Massive Attack on Diseases of Poverty.”(a paper to WHO Cabinet and Regional Offices), Geneva, March 14, 2000</ref><ref>”G8 Experts’ Meeting on Global Health Issues: Summary of Discussion.” April 19–20, 2000.</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.mofa.go.jp/policy/economy/summit/2000/documents/communique.html|title=MOFA: G8 COMMUNIQUÉ OKINAWA 2000|website=www.mofa.go.jp|language=en|access-date=2018-07-14}}</ref>
In April 2001, in Abuja, Nigeria at a summit of African leaders, [[Secretary-General of the United Nations|United Nations Secretary General]] [[Kofi Annan]] made the first explicit public call by a highly visible global leader for this new funding mechanism, proposing "the creation of a Global Fund, dedicated to the battle against HIV/AIDS and other infectious diseases."<ref name="Kofi Annan">{{cite web|url=https://www.un.org/News/ossg/sg/stories/statments_search_full.asp?statID=8 |title=Annan's call for a global AIDS war chest |publisher=United Nations |date=2001-04-26 |accessdate=2012-01-26}}</ref> Secretary General Annan made the first contribution to the Global Fund in 2001. Having just been named the recipient of the 2001 [[Philadelphia Liberty Medal]], Annan announced he would donate his USD 100,000 award to the Global Fund "war chest" he had just proposed creating.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://news.un.org/en/story/2001/06/4102-global-aids-fund-should-be-and-running-years-end-annan-says|title=Global AIDS Fund should be up and running by year's end, Annan says|date=2001-06-27|work=UN News|access-date=2018-07-10|language=en}}</ref> In June 2001 the [[United Nations General Assembly]] endorsed the creation of a global fund to fight HIV/AIDS.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.un.org/ga/aids/docs/aress262.pdf|title=Declaration of Commitment on HIV/AIDS|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=July 14, 2018}}</ref>
The G8 formally endorsed the call for the creation of the Global Fund at its summit in July 2001 in [[Genoa|Genoa, Italy]], although pledges were significantly lower than the USD 7 billion to USD 10 billion annually Kofi Annan insisted was needed.<ref name="G8 Leaders Agree to Create AIDS Fund">{{cite web|last=Washington |first=The |url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2001/jul/20/20010720-024354-4327r/print/ |title=G8 Leaders Agree to Create AIDS Fund |publisher=Washington Times |date=2001-07-20 |accessdate=2012-01-26}}</ref> According to the G8’s final communique, “At Okinawa last year, we pledged to make a quantum leap in the fight against infectious diseases and to break the vicious cycle between disease and poverty. To meet that commitment and to respond to the appeal of the UN General Assembly, we have launched with the UN Secretary-General a new Global Fund to fight HIV/AIDS, malaria and tuberculosis. We are determined to make the Fund operational before the end of the year. We have committed $1.3 billion. The Fund will be a public-private partnership and we call on other countries, the private sector, foundations, and academic institutions to join with their own contributions - financially, in kind and through shared expertise.”<ref name="Genoa">{{cite web|url=http://www.g8.utoronto.ca/summit/2001genoa/finalcommunique.html |title=G8 Communique, July 22, 2001 |publisher= utoronto.ca |date= |accessdate=2012-01-26}}</ref>
The Global Fund's initial 18-member policy-setting board held its first meeting in January 2002, and issued its first call for proposals.<ref name="First board meeting">{{cite journal | last1 = Kapp | first1 = C. | title = Global fund on AIDS, tuberculosis, and malaria holds first board meeting. | journal = Lancet | volume = 359 | issue = 9304 | page = 414 |date=February 2002 | doi = 10.1016/S0140-6736(02)07634-1 | pmid = 11844526 }}</ref> <ref>{{Cite journal|last=Hanefeld|first=Johanna|date=2014-02-01|title=The Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria: 10 years on|url=http://www.clinmed.rcpjournal.org/content/14/1/54|journal=Clinical Medicine|language=en|volume=14|issue=1|pages=54–57|doi=10.7861/clinmedicine.14-1-54|issn=1470-2118|pmid=24532746}}</ref> The first secretariat was established in January 2002 with Paul Ehmer serving as team leader, soon replaced by [[Anders Nordstrom]] of Sweden who became the organization’s interim executive director. By the time the Global Fund Secretariat became operational, the organization had received USD 1.9 billion in pledges.
In March 2002, a panel of international public health experts was named to begin reviewing project proposals that same month. In April 2002, the Global Fund awarded its first batch of grants – worth USD 378 million – to fight the three diseases in 31 countries.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.globalhealthdelivery.org/case-collection/concept-notes/the-global-fund-to-fight-aids-tubercu|title=Concept Note: The Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria|access-date=2018-07-14|language=en}}</ref>
==Fundraising== Since the Global Fund was created in 2002, public sector contributions have constituted 95 percent of all financing raised; the remaining 5 percent comes from the [[private sector]] or other financing initiatives such as [[Product Red]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theglobalfund.org/en/government/ |title=Government Donors - The Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria |publisher=The Global Fund |date=2018-05-23 |accessdate=2018-05-23}}</ref> The Global Fund states that from 2002 to 2016, more than 51 donor governments pledged a total of USD 38.5 billion and paid USD 37.3 billion.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theglobalfund.org/media/1119/core_pledgescontributions_list_en.xlsx |title=Pledges and Contributions - The Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria |publisher=The Global Fund |date=2018-03-31 |accessdate=2018-05-23}}</ref> From 2001 through 2016, the largest contributor by far has been the [[United States]], followed by [[France]], the [[United Kingdom]], [[Germany]], and [[Japan]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theglobalfund.org/media/1119/core_pledgescontributions_list_en.xlsx |title=Pledges and Contributions - The Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria |publisher=The Global Fund |date=2018-03-31 |accessdate=2018-05-23}}</ref> The donor nations with the largest percent of [[gross national income]] contributed to the fund from 2008 through 2010 were [[Sweden]], [[Norway]], France, the [[United Kingdom]], the [[Netherlands]], and [[Spain]].{{Citation needed|date=May 2018}}
The Global Fund typically raises and spends funds during three-year "replenishment" fund-raising periods. Its first replenishment was launched in 2005, the second in 2007, the third in 2010, the fourth in 2013, and the fifth in 2016.<ref>{{cite web|title=Replenishment Archive|url=https://www.theglobalfund.org/en/archive/replenishment/|publisher=The Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria|accessdate=23 May 2018}}</ref>
Alarms were raised prior to the third replenishment meeting in October 2010 about a looming deficit in funding, which would have led to people undergoing ARV treatment losing access, increasing the chance of them becoming resistant to treatment. [[UNAIDS]] Executive Director [[Michel Sidibé]] dubbed the scenario of a funding deficit an "HIV Nightmare".<ref>Hellevik, Siri Bjerkrem: [http://blog.nibrinternational.no/#post20 "Is an HIV Nightmare on the Way?"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160624015615/http://blog.nibrinternational.no/ |date=2016-06-24 }} at ''the NIBR International Blog, August 23, 2010''</ref> The Global Fund stated it needed at least USD 20 billion for the third replenishment (covering programs 2011-2013), and USD 13 billion just to "allow for the continuation of funding of existing programs."<ref>Hellevik, Siri Bjerkreim: ''HIV Nightmare Averted - For Now'', [http://blog.nibrinternational.no/#post22 NIBR International Blog, October 14, 2020] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160624015615/http://blog.nibrinternational.no/ |date=June 24, 2016 }}</ref> Ultimately, USD 11.8 billion was mobilized at the third replenishment meeting, with the United States being the largest contributor - followed by France, Germany, and Japan. The Global Fund stated the USD 1.2 billion lack in funding would "lead to difficult decisions in the next three years that could slow down the effort to beat the three diseases."<ref>Hellevik, Siri Bjerkreim: H''IV Nightmare Averted - For Now'', [http://blog.nibrinternational.no/#post22 NIBR International Blog, October 14, 2020] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160624015615/http://blog.nibrinternational.no/ |date=June 24, 2016 }}</ref>
In November 2011, the organization's board cancelled all new grants for 2012, only having enough money to support existing grants.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2011/12/01/143024108/obama-embraces-end-of-aids-promises-to-accelerate-hiv-treatment|title=Obama Embraces 'End of AIDS,' Promises To Accelerate HIV Treatment|work=NPR.org|access-date=2017-04-21|language=en}}</ref> However, following the Global Fund’s May 2012 board meeting, it announced that an additional USD 1.6 billion would be available in the 2012-2014 period for investment in programs.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.theglobalfund.org/en/mediacenter/newsreleases/2012-05-09_Global_Fund_Forecasts_USD_1_6_billion_in_Available_Funds_for_2012_2014_Major_Shift_Reflects_Strategic_Choices_by_Board_Renewed_Confidence/ |title=Global Fund Forecasts $1.6 billion in Available Funds for 2012-2014 |accessdate=19 August 2012}}</ref>
In December 2013, the fourth replenishment meeting was held in Washington D.C. USD 12 billion was pledged in contributions from 25 countries, as well as the European Commission, private foundations, corporations, and faith-based organizations for the 2014-2016 period.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.voanews.com/content/global-fund-replenishment-5dec13/1804174.html|title=Donors Pledge $12 Billion for Global Fund|work=VOA}}</ref> It was the largest amount ever committed to fighting the three diseases.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blog.results.org.uk/2013/12/05/historic-replenishment-of-the-global-fund-to-fight-aids-tb-and-malaria-only-a-starting-point/|title=Historic Replenishment of the Global Fund to Fight AIDS, TB and Malaria Only a Starting Point|work=results.org.uk|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140830051238/http://blog.results.org.uk/2013/12/05/historic-replenishment-of-the-global-fund-to-fight-aids-tb-and-malaria-only-a-starting-point/|archivedate=2014-08-30|df=}}</ref>
The fifth replenishment meeting took place September 2016 in [[Montreal]], Canada, and was hosted by Canadian Prime Minister [[Justin Trudeau]]. Donors pledged USD 12.9 billion for the 2017-2019 period.<ref>{{cite web|title=Global fund raises $12.9 billion to fight AIDS, TB and malaria|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-health-aids-fundraising-idUSKCN11N0PB|website=Reuters|publisher=Reuters|accessdate=17 September 2016}}</ref>
France and French President [[Emmanuel Macron]] will host the sixth replenishment meeting in 2019 for the 2020-2022 period.<ref>{{cite web|title=France to host 6th conference for global fund to fight AIDS, TB, malaria|url=http://www.xinhuanet.com/english/2018-05/16/c_137184265.htm|website=Xinhua|publisher=Xinhua|accessdate=16 May 2018}}</ref>
==Leadership== [[Richard Feachem]] was named the Global Fund's first executive director in April 2002<ref name="Feachem named head of Global Fund">{{cite web |url=http://www.healthgap.org/press_releases/a02/042502_BG_FUND_ED.html |title=FUND: Executive Director Feecham, 4/25/02 |publisher=Healthgap.org |date=2002-04-25 |accessdate=2012-01-26 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110928061453/http://www.healthgap.org/press_releases/a02/042502_BG_FUND_ED.html |archivedate=2011-09-28 |df= }}</ref> and faced early crticism from activists for stating the Global Fund has "plenty" of money to start.<ref name="Disease-fighting group gets off to rocky start">Disease-fighting group gets off to rocky start, The Boston Globe, July 1, 2002.</ref>
Feachem served from July 2002 through March 2007. Dr. [[Michel Kazatchkine]] was then selected as executive director over the Global Fund’s architect, [[David Nabarro]], even though Nabarro was “considered the strongest of three shortlisted candidates to head the Global Fund ... A selection committee has evaluated the three nominees' qualifications and ranked ‘Nabarro first, Kazatchkine second and (Alex) Cotinho third,’ according to a Fund source.”<ref name="UN's Nabarro tipped to head global AIDS fund">UN's Nabarro tipped to head global AIDS fund, “Reuters Health Medical News,'' February 1, 2007.</ref>
In September 2011, the [[AIDS Healthcare Foundation]] called for Kazatchkine's resignation in the wake of isolated yet unprecedented reports of "waste, fraud, and corruption" in order that "reforms may begin in earnest."<ref>{{cite web|title=AHF: Global Fund Head Must Step Down to Ensure Fund’s Viability|url=http://www.aidshealth.org/news/press-releases/ahf-global-fund-head-must.html|publisher=AIDS Healthcare Foundation|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111006065951/http://www.aidshealth.org/news/press-releases/ahf-global-fund-head-must.html|archivedate=2011-10-06|df=}}</ref> In January 2012, Kazatchkine ultimately declared his resignation, following the decision made by the Global Fund board in November 2011 to appoint a general manager, leaving Kazatchkine’s role to that of chief fund-raiser and public advocate.<ref>{{cite news |last=Mcneil|first=Donald Jr. |title=Director Quits After Changes at Global Fund|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/01/25/health/global-funds-executive-director-steps-down.html}}</ref> Communications later disclosed by the United States government stated that Kazatchkine's performance was deemed unsatisfactory by the Global Fund board, notably in relation to the funding of activities related to the First Lady of France at the time, [[Carla Bruni-Sarkozy]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Hillary Clinton Archives Reveal AIDS Fund Chief Pushed Out in 2012|url=http://www.ndtv.com/world-news/hillary-clinton-archives-reveal-aids-fund-chief-pushed-out-in-2012-1238601}}</ref>
Following Kazatchkine’s resignation, the Global Fund announced the appointment of Gabriel Jaramillo, the former Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of Sovereign Bank, to the newly created position of general manager. Jaramillo, who had retired one year earlier, had since served as a Special Advisor to the Office of the Special Envoy for Malaria of the Secretary General of the United Nations, and was a member of the high-level independent panel that looked at the Global Fund’s fiduciary controls and oversight mechanisms. Jaramillo reorganized and reduced Global Fund staff in response to the previous year's critics of the Global Fund.<ref>{{cite web|title=Gabriel Jaramillo, former General Manager of The Global Fund|url=https://www.hsph.harvard.edu/voices/events/jaramillo/|website=Harvard T.H. Chan School of Public Health|publisher=Harvard T.H. Chan School of Public Health|accessdate=3 April 2014}}</ref>
Dr. [[Mark Dybul|Mark R. Dybul]] was appointed executive director in November 2012.<ref>{{cite web|title=Global Fund Board Selects Mark Dybul to Be the Fund’s Next Executive Directo|url=http://www.aidspan.org/gfo_article/global-fund-board-selects-mark-dybul-be-fund%E2%80%99s-next-executive-director|website=Aidspan|publisher=Aidspan|accessdate=16 November 2012}}</ref> He previously served as the United States Global AIDS Coordinator, leading the implementation of the [[President's Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief]] (PEPFAR) from 2006 to 2009. Dybul ended his appointment in 2017.
A nominating process to find a successor to Dybul ran into trouble in 2017 because nominees had spoken out against [[Donald Trump]] as a candidate for president of the United States.<ref>https://www.nytimes.com/2017/02/15/health/global-fund-aids-tuberculosis-malaria-director.html?action=click&contentCollection=Health&module=RelatedCoverage&region=Marginalia&pgtype=article</ref> The Global Fund board named Global Fund Chief of Staff Marijke Wijnroks of the Netherlands as interim executive director while the nominating process restarted. <ref>https://www.ip-watch.org/2017/03/04/global-fund-names-interim-executive-director-starting-june/</ref>
The Global Fund board selected banker [[Peter Sands (banker)| Peter Sands]] as executive director in 2017.<ref>{{cite web|title=Peter Sands Named Head of Global Disease-Fighting Agency|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/11/14/health/peter-sands-global-fund.html|website=The New York Times|publisher=The New York Times|accessdate=14 November 2017}}</ref> He assumed the role in 2018.
==Operations== The Global Fund was formed as an independent, non-profit foundation under Swiss law and hosted by the [[World Health Organization]] in January 2002.<ref>{{cite web|title=Global Fund Overview|url=http://www.theglobalfund.org/en/overview/|website=Wayback Machine|publisher=The Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria|accessdate=22 November 2016|deadurl=bot: unknown|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161122071114/http://www.theglobalfund.org/en/overview/|archivedate=22 November 2016|df=}}</ref> In January 2009, the organization became an administratively autonomous organization, terminating its administrative services agreement with the World Health Organization.<ref>{{cite web |title=The Global Fund becomes an administratively autonomous institution as of 2009 |url=https://www.theglobalfund.org/en/news/2008-12-19-the-global-fund-becomes-an-administratively-autonomous-institution-as-of-2009/ |website=The Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria |publisher=The Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria |accessdate=16 August 2017}}</ref>
The initial objective of the Global Fund — to provide funding to countries on the basis of performance — was supposed to make it different from other international agencies at the time of its inception. Other organizations may have staff that assist with the implementation of grants. However, the Global Fund's five-year evaluation in 2009 concluded that without a standing body of technical staff, the Global Fund is not able to ascertain the actual results of its projects.{{Citation needed|date=May 2018}} It has therefore tended to look at disbursements or the purchase of inputs as performance.{{Citation needed|date=May 2018}} It also became apparent shortly after the organization opened that a pure funding mechanism could not work on its own, and it began relying on other agencies – notably the World Health Organization – to support countries in designing and drafting their applications and in supporting implementation.{{Citation needed|date=May 2018}} The [[United Nations Development Programme]], in particular, bears responsibility for supporting Global Fund-financed projects in a number of countries.{{Citation needed|date=May 2018}} As a result, the organization is most accurately described as a financial supplement to the existing global health architecture rather than as a separate approach.
The Global Fund Secretariat in Geneva, Switzerland, employs about 700 staff.<ref>{{cite web |title=Staff |url=https://www.theglobalfund.org/en/staff |website=The Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria |publisher=The Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria |accessdate=16 August 2017}}</ref> There are neither offices nor staff based in other countries.<ref>{{cite web |title=Overview |url=https://www.theglobalfund.org/en/overview |website=The Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria |publisher=The Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria |accessdate=28 May 2018}}</ref>
In 2013, the Global Fund adopted a new way of distributing its funds in countries to fight AIDS, tuberculosis and malaria.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Lopez Gonzalez |first1=Laura |title=A beginner’s guide to the Global Fund’s new funding model |url=http://www.makingmalariahistory.org/a-beginners-guide-to-the-global-funds-new-funding-model/ |website=Making Malaria History |publisher=Global Health Posts |accessdate=16 August 2017}}</ref> Under this funding model, eligible countries receive an allocation of money every three years for possible use during same the three-year period.<ref>{{cite news |title=The Global Fund launches new funding model to support countries in responding to HIV, TB and malaria |url=http://www.unaids.org/en/resources/presscentre/featurestories/2013/march/20130301agfatm |accessdate=16 August 2017 |agency=The Global Fund launches new funding model to support countries in responding to HIV, TB and malaria |publisher=UNAIDS |date=1 March 2013}}</ref> The total amount of all allocations across all countries depends on the amount contributed by governments and other donors through the "replenishment" fundraising during the same three-year period.<ref>{{cite journal |title=The Global Fund's New Funding Model:What it Might Mean for You and Your Country |journal=Eurasian Harm Reduction Network |date=March 2013 |page=8 |url=http://ecom.ngo/wp-content/uploads/2016/07/3.pdf}}</ref> The countries, through their “country coordinating mechanism” committees, submit applications outlining how they’ll use the allocation.<ref>{{cite journal |title=Understanding the New Funding Model: An Aidspan Guide |date=30 April 2014 |page=7 |url=http://www.aidspan.org/sites/all/modules/custom/apw_zstatistic/publication_download.php?file=sites/default/files/publications/NFM_Guide.pdf |accessdate=16 August 2017}}</ref> The committees name entities, called “principal recipients,” to carry about programs within their respective countries.<ref>{{cite journal |title=Understanding the New Funding Model: An Aidspan Guide |date=30 April 2014 |page=8 |url=http://www.aidspan.org/sites/all/modules/custom/apw_zstatistic/publication_download.php?file=sites/default/files/publications/NFM_Guide.pdf |accessdate=16 August 2017}}</ref> An independent "technical review panel" reviews the applications.<ref>{{cite journal |title=The Global Fund's New Funding Model: Early Outcomes for Regional Civil Society Applicants |journal=ICASO |date=March 2014 |page=13 |url=http://icaso.org/wp-content/uploads/2015/06/erhnNewFundingModelweb.pdf |accessdate=16 August 2017}}</ref> Once the applications are approved, the Global Fund provides funding to the principal recipients based on achievement toward agreed indicators and actual expenses.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=The Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria |title=Operational Policy Manual |date=7 March 2018 |url=https://www.theglobalfund.org/media/3266/core_operationalpolicy_manual_en.pdf |accessdate=28 May 2018}}</ref> Performance and expenses are periodically reviewed by a “local fund agent,” which in most countries is an international financial audit company.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Rivers |first1=Bernard |title=What is a Local Fund Agent? |url=http://www.aidspan.org/gfo_article/what-local-fund-agent |website=Aidspan |publisher=Aidspan |accessdate=23 January 2003}}</ref>
==Corruption and misuse of funds== In January 2011, the [[Associated Press]] reported vast corruption in some programs financed by the Global Fund, citing findings of the Global Fund Office of the Inspector General -- an auditing unit independent from the Global Fund Secretariat -- that up to two-thirds of funds in some of the reviewed grants were lost to fraud.<ref name="ap-report" /> The Office of the Inspector General report showed that systematic fraud patterns had been used across countries.<ref name="ap-report" /> The Global Fund responded to the story with a news release, stating, "The Global Fund has zero tolerance for corruption and actively seeks to uncover any evidence of misuse of its funds. It deploys some of the most rigorous procedures to detect fraud and fight corruption of any organization financing development."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theglobalfund.org/en/mediacenter/newsreleases/2011-01-24_Gobal_Fund_statement_on_abuse_of_funds_in_some_countries/ |title=News Release: Global Fund statement on abuse of funds in some countries. |publisher=The Global Fund |date=January 24, 2011 |accessdate=2012-01-26 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120830145403/http://www.theglobalfund.org/en/mediacenter/newsreleases/2011-01-24_Gobal_Fund_statement_on_abuse_of_funds_in_some_countries/ |archivedate=August 30, 2012 }}</ref>
After the Associated Press story, a number of op-eds, including one by [[Michael Gerson]] published in the Washington Post in February 2011, sought to put the controversy surrounding the misuse of Global Fund grants in perspective. Gerson stated, "The two-thirds figure applies to one element of one country's grant - the single most extreme example in the world. Investigations are ongoing, but the $34 million in fraud that has been exposed represents about three-tenths of 1 percent of the money the fund has distributed. The targeting of these particular cases was not random; they were the most obviously problematic, not the most typical."<ref name="washingtonpost.com">{{cite news| url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2011/02/03/AR2011020305176.html | work=The Washington Post | first=Michael | last=Gerson | title=Putting fraud in global health spending in context | date=February 4, 2011}}</ref>
Global Fund spokesman Jon Liden told the Associated Press, "The messenger is being shot to some extent. We would contend that we do not have any corruption problems that are significantly different in scale or nature to any other international financing institution."<ref name="ap-report">{{cite news |title=AP Enterprise: Fraud plagues global health fund |author= |url=http://archive.boston.com/news/world/europe/articles/2011/01/23/ap_enterprise_fraud_plagues_global_health_fund/ |agency=Associated Press |date=23 January 2011 |accessdate=6 October 2016}}</ref> Subsequent Global Fund statements omitted any reference to other agencies.{{Citation needed|date=June 2018}}
Previous reviews of grants and the Global Fund had shown substantial misconduct in some programs, lack of adequate risk management, and operational inefficiency of the Global Fund.<ref>[http://www.theglobalfund.org/en/terg/evaluations/5year/ Summary Paper on the Five-Year Evaluation Synthesis Report] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100210124517/http://www.theglobalfund.org/en/terg/evaluations/5year/ |date=2010-02-10 }}, 5-year review study paid by the GFATM pp13, 2009</ref> Cases of corruption had also been found in several African countries such as Mali, Mauritania, Djibouti, and Zambia.<ref name="ap-report" />
Sweden, the Global Fund’s 11th biggest contributor at the time (2011), suspended its USD 85 million annual donation until the corruption problems were resolved.<ref name="ap-report"/> Germany, the third biggest contributor at the time, also blocked any financing until a special investigation was complete.<ref>[http://www.bmz.de/de/presse/aktuelleMeldungen/2011/januar/20110125_pm_10_globalerfonds/index.html Minister Niebel on Corruption at the GFATM] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110717125000/http://www.bmz.de/de/presse/aktuelleMeldungen/2011/januar/20110125_pm_10_globalerfonds/index.html |date=2011-07-17 }}, BMZ message, January 25, 2011 German only</ref> Funding was eventually restored.
Other cases of abuse of funds, corruption and mismanagement in a series of grants forced the Global Fund to suspend or terminate the grants after such dealings became publicly known in Uganda, Zimbabwe, Philippines, and Ukraine.{{Citation needed|date=May 2018}}
In February 2011, the Financial Times reported that the Global Fund board failed to act previously on concerns over accountability including on the conclusion of an external evaluation in 2009 that criticized the organization’s weak procurement practices.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Jack |first1=Andrew |title=UN health fund to review practices |url=https://www.ft.com/content/bd2d513a-2fcd-11e0-91f8-00144feabdc0 |accessdate=4 June 2018 |agency=Financial Times |publisher=Financial Times |date=4 February 2011}}</ref> Warnings of inadequate controls had also been reported periodically.<ref>A spoonful of ingenuity, The Economist, Jan. 7, 2010.</ref> The Financial Times also reported that its own review found that neither Global Fund staff nor “local fund agents” (the entities entrusted with audit-like tasks at the country level) had noticed the deficiencies reported by the inspector general.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Jack |first1=Andrew |title=UN health fund to review practices |url=https://www.ft.com/content/bd2d513a-2fcd-11e0-91f8-00144feabdc0 |accessdate=4 June 2018 |agency=Financial Times |publisher=Financial Times |date=4 February 2011}}</ref>
In 2012, the Global Fund hired a chief risk officer, Cees Klumper.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Mungcal |first1=Ivy |title=Cees Klumper is Global Fund’s new chief risk officer |url=https://www.devex.com/news/cees-klumper-is-global-fund-s-new-chief-risk-officer-77852 |accessdate=27 March 2012 |agency=Devex |publisher=Devex |date=27 March 2012}}</ref> After pushing countries to reclaim stolen funds from the parties responsible and recovering only about half, the organization began in 2014 as a last resort reducing future grants by twice the amount of misappropriated funds.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Nurith |first1=Aizenman |title=Meet The Repo Man For Global Health: Skim Off A Grant, He'll Make You Pay |url=https://www.npr.org/sections/goatsandsoda/2016/02/09/466143083/meet-the-repo-man-for-global-health-skim-off-a-grant-hell-make-you-pay |accessdate=9 February 2016 |agency=National Public Radio |publisher=National Public Radio |date=9 February 2016}}</ref> As of February 2016, this resulted in USD 14.8 million of reductions (collectively) for Bangladesh, Guatemala, Nigeria and Sri Lanka.{{Citation needed|date=June 2018}}{{update-inline|date=March 2016}}

The '''WIN Party''' was a small political party in [[New Zealand]].
It was founded by a group of [[public house|publican]]s and [[bar (establishment)|bar-owners]] who objected to the government's [[smoking ban|ban on smoking]] in bars and restaurants, introduced in December 2004. WIN's slogan was "Freedom of Choice", and the party said that it was fighting a growing trend in which "the average Kiwi ... is being told more and more what they can and can't do". According to the party's leaders, opposition to the smoking ban was the party's primary campaign plank, but other related issues were also given attention.
WIN's leader was [[John van Buren (New Zealand)|John van Buren]], a publican from the [[Banks Peninsula]] area. Geoff Mulvihill, a publican from [[Timaru]], was the deputy leader. Both van Buren and Mulvihill have been accused by the Ministry of Health of not enforcing the smoking ban, as required by law. Mulvihill is known for supporting freedom of choice for his patrons, having once lost his liquor licence for operating around the clock prior to the legislation of 24-hour trading.<ref name="TVNZ_661073">{{cite web |url=http://tvnz.co.nz/view/page/411749/661073 |title=Publican claims victimisation |date=15 February 2006 |work=[[Television New Zealand]] |accessdate=11 September 2011}}</ref><ref name="NZ_Herald_10360062">{{cite web |url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/bars/news/article.cfm?c_id=687&objectid=10360062 |title=Publican 'blatantly flouted' law against smoking |author=Jarrod Booker |date=15 December 2005 |work=[[The New Zealand Herald]] |accessdate=10 September 2011}}</ref> The party had been given official registration, but chose not to field candidates in the [[New Zealand general election, 2005|2005 elections]]. Instead, it endorsed the larger [[United Future New Zealand|United Future]] party, and van Buren stood as a candidate on United Future's party list, where he was ranked 55th out of 57.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://electionresults.govt.nz/electionresults_2005/e9/html/e9_part3_1.html|title=Party Lists of Successful Registered Parties|website=electionresults.govt.nz|access-date=2017-01-23}}</ref> As United Future received only three seats in Parliament at that election, van Buren was not elected.
The party published the results of a survey showing that while city bars had suffered little damage from the ban on patrons choosing to smoke, suburban and rural establishments had been hard hit.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.smh.com.au/news/world/prosmoking-nz-publican-fined-in-test-case/2005/12/16/1134703597110.html | work=The Sydney Morning Herald | title=Pro-smoking NZ publican fined in test case | date=16 December 2005}}</ref>
WIN was deregistered in August 2006.<ref>[http://www.elections.org.nz/news/cancel-party-regi.html Cancellation of party registration | Elections New Zealand<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>

The '''World Database of Happiness''' <ref>http://www1.eur.nl/fsw/happiness/index.html</ref> is a web-based archive of research findings on subjective appreciation of life. The database contains both an overview of scientific publications on happiness and a digest of research findings.<ref>Veenhoven, R. (2004) World database of happiness; Continuous register of research on subjective appreciation of life. Published in: Glatzer, W., VonBelow, S. & Stoffregen, M. (eds.), ‘Challenges for quality of life in the contemporary world: Advances in quality-of-life studies, theory and research’, Kluwer Academic Publishers, Dordrecht The Netherlands, Social Indicators Research Series, vol. 24, {{ISBN|1-4020-2890-3}} (e-book 1-4020-2903-9).</ref> The database contains information on how happy people are in a wide range of circumstances and in 165 different nations.<ref>Veenhoven, R. (2011) World database of happiness; Example of a focused ‘Findings Archive’. Published as Working paper No. 169, German Data Forum RatSWD, February 2011.</ref> Happiness is defined as the degree to which an individual judges the quality of his or her life as a whole favorably. Two 'components' of happiness are distinguished: hedonic level of affect (the degree to which pleasant affect dominates) and contentment (perceived realization of wants).
==Aims== The World Database of Happiness is a tool to acquire an overview on the ever-growing stream of research findings on happiness. The accumulation of knowledge stagnates if scientists do not capitalize on earlier research investments.<ref>Veenhoven, R. (2009) World database of happiness. Psychological Topics, 18: 221-246.</ref> Medio 2013 the database covered some 19,000 scientific findings on happiness, of which about 6000 are distributional findings (on how happy people are) and another 13,000 correlational findings (on what is associated with more and less happiness).<ref>http://www1.eur.nl/fsw/happiness/index.html</ref> The first findings date from 1915.
==Popular use== The World Database of Happiness is often used by popular media to make lists of the happiest countries around the globe.<ref>http://www.gfmag.com/tools/global-database/ne-data/11940-happiest-countries.html#axzz2VQh2jLfD</ref> An example is the [[Happy Planet Index]], which aims to chart sustainable happiness all over the world by combining data on [[longevity]], [[happiness]] and the size of the [[ecological footprint]] of citizens.<ref>http://www.happyplanetindex.org/</ref>
==Strengths and weaknesses== The database has a clear conceptual focus, it includes only research findings on subjective enjoyment of one’s life as a whole. Thereby it evades the Babel that has haunted the study of happiness for ages. The other side of that coin is that much interesting research is left out. The findings are reported with technical details about measurement and statistical analysis. This detail is welcomed by scholars, but makes the information difficult to digest for lay-persons. Still another limitation is that the available findings are often contradictory, which makes it hard to draw firm conclusions about the causes of happiness. What is clear is that poor health, separation, unemployment and lack of social contact are all strongly negatively associated with unhappiness.<ref>Dolan, P., Peasgood, T. & White, M. (2008). Do we really know what makes us happy? A review of the economic literature on the factors associated with subjective well-being. Journal of Economic Psychology, 29, 94-122.</ref> Another problem for the World database of happiness is that the number of studies on happiness increases with such a high rate that it gets increasingly difficult to offer a complete overview of all research findings.
